clauses.question: 2. If the Government sets a 2050 target now, which is the best target for New Zealand?
clauses.answer: Net Zero Long-Lived Gases and Stabilised Short-Lived Gases - Long-lived gases to net zero by 2050 while also stabilising short-lived gases
clauses.notes:
Currently figures attributed to agricultural emissions is a gross value and it has to be calculated as a net emission because it is a flow

 pollutant not a stock.

clauses.question: 3. How should New Zealand meet its targets?
clauses.answer: Domestic emissions reductions only (including from new forest planting)

clauses.question: 4. Should the Zero Carbon Bill allow the 2050 target to be revised if circumstances change?
5. The Government proposes that three emissions budgets of five years each (i.e. covering the next 15 years) be in place at any given time. Do you agree with this proposal?
6. Should the Government be able to alter the last emissions budget (i.e. furthest into the future)?
clauses.answer: Yes - the third emissions budget should be able to be changed but only when the subsequent budget is set

clauses.question: 9. Should the Zero Carbon Bill require Governments to set out plans within a certain timeframe to achieve the emissions budgets?
14. Do you think the Zero Carbon Bill should cover adapting to climate change?
Do you have any other comments you'd like to make?
clauses.notes:
Native forests should be included as well as pre 1990 forests planted that won't be harvested. We live on a farm with significant native

 bush. Over the years while others have cleared bush our family has preserved it - there is so much bush on our farm that we have
 very little room for new plantings. There should be some credit for this ongoing conservation work and commitment to offsetting our
 on farm emissions. Likewise, we market the food products from our farm - it will become more and more important for consumers to

 have the ability to choose products from 'carbon neutral' or positive producers. Our stock numbers are low, we don't irrigate, our
fertiliser use is very limited - however, because we don't have the space for new plantings - technically we will sit next to more heavy

polluters and gives an unfair impression of the nature of our business and our commitment to reducing greenhouse gas levels. If the
government is to go beyond its current Paris commitments, I encourage the government to also take a more flexible approach to

measuring emissions offsets, that are genuinely sequestering carbon. The international rules do allow alternative metrics. As a
business and a family we care deeply about the environment and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Historically we have done our

bit and want to continue our efforts in this area and do even better. Please help us to achieve our goals.
